description.narrative:
In a region where securing Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights (SRHR) is especially challenging, Masarouna will mobilize the power of young people’s collective action in six Middle East and North Africa (MENA) countries to support their fight for greater freedom of choice and respect for their SRHR through new and innovative pathways for change. Our vision is that young people (YP) meaningfully induce sustainable change that will enable them to enjoy their SRHR. Jordan is one of the countries where the Masarouna programme will be implemented.
Context: In 2019, 41.4% of MENA’s population was aged 15-39, making it one of the world’s youngest regions. In recent years, young people have demonstrated their ability to become main drivers for change in response to long-standing structural inequalities, rising authoritarianism and increased levels of conflict and fragility. Young people in MENA continue to facesome of the most vocal conservative opposition to their SRHR. The problem that Masarouna will tackle is the perpetual obfuscation and the increasing weaponization of SRHR as a form of social control. This strips SRHR of the urgency it deserves, yet, we strongly believe fulfilling young people’s SRHR can have a transformative effect on sustainable development due to its connection with basic human well-being and gender equality. Strategic objective: Young people in six selected countries in the MENA region achieve more freedom to enjoy their SRHR in inclusive societies. Targeted group: Young people aged 18-35, in particular (unmarried) women and LGBTQI+. Activists and individuals will be mobilized as agents and drivers of change throughout the programme cycle.
The programme’s strategic objective and outcomes contribute directly to achieving SDGs 3 (health and well-being), 5 (gender equality) and 10 (reduced inequalities. The programme is fully aligned with the ICPD25 Nairobi statement’s call for renewed commitments towards women’s and Young People’s SRHR.
The Masarouna programme implements two main pathways of change:
1: Lobby and advocacy with young people for theirSRHR The first pathway promotes greater accountability of governments to adhere to international SRHR standards, human rights frameworks and agreements; promotes young people’s active and meaningful involvement in policy agenda-setting and decision-making; and increases public awareness on SRHR, including through media engagement, aiming to create new narratives on SRHR.
2: Strengthening civil society and reinventing civic space A strong civilsociety can be a mobilizer, an amplifier of voices and a watchdog. With strengthened capacities, CSOs can create a sense of urgency around SRHR to push for sustainable change. CSOs need the space to play this political role, which Masarouna aims to reinvent by promoting the political activation and participation of young people and creating and strengthening alternative civic spaces, both online and offline. Working online allows for reaching young people at scale by circumventing gatekeepers and mitigating risks around censorship.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam is an international confederation of 17 organizations working together in more than 90 countries. Oxfam International was formed in 1995 by a group of independent non-governmental organizations. Their aim was to work together for greater impact on the international stage to reduce poverty and injustice. The name ?Oxfam? comes from the Oxford Committee for Famine Relief, founded in Britain in 1942. The group campaigned for food supplies to be sent through an allied naval blockade to starving women and children in enemy-occupied Greece during the Second World War. As well as becoming a world leader in the delivery of emergency relief, Oxfam International implements long-term development programs in vulnerable communities. We are also part of a global movement, campaigning withothers, for instance, to end unfair trade rules, demand better health and education services for all, and to combat climate change.Today, there are 17 member organizations of the Oxfam International confederation. They are based in: Australia, Belgium, Canada, France, Germany, Great Britain, Hong Kong, Ireland, India, Italy, Japan, Mexico, The Netherlands, New Zealand, Quebec, Spain and the United States. The Oxfam International Secretariat is based in Oxford, UK. The Secretariat runs advocacy offices in Brussels, Geneva, New York, Washington DC and Brasilia. Oxfam GB is an actor in the implementation of this project.

EO1 Young people and civil society are capacitated to advocate for safe, adequate and inclusive SRHR information and services
KI-6 # CSOs/movements, both women and youth led, capacitated by Masarouna to advocate for safe and adequate SRHR information and services for diverse young people

comment.narrative: A Mutual Capacity Strengthening baseline survey was conducted in 2021, screening seven different capacities under the topic of influencing and awareness raising on SRHR for young people. These are: developing an influencing strategy, youth-led influencing, lobby and/or advocacy on policies and practices, public campaigning, digital campaigning, working with traditional media, and influencing social norms. The topics for which most of the organizations involved in Masarouna expressed a need on capacity strengthening, are: lobby and/or advocacy on policies and practices, digital campaigning, and developing an influencing strategy. The topics for which most organizations indicated to already having a strong capacity and being able to support others, are: youth-led influencing, public campaigning, developing an influencing strategy, and working with traditional media. (Organisations could express a need, an offer, or both a need and offer on the same topic).

Capacity strengthening in relation to influencing on SRHR for diverse young people will focus on the needs as expressed by respective organisations involved in Masarouna. These include capacity strengthening on lobby and/or advocacy on policies and practices, digital campaigning, and developing an influencing strategy. This capacity strengthening will also be offered to CSOs who are not Masarouna contracted partners, for instance some youth-led organisations.

description.narrative: KI-6 # CSOs/movements, not women or youth led, capacitated by Masarouna to advocate for safe and adequate SRHR information and services for diverse young people

comment.narrative:
According to the Mutual Capacity Strengthening baseline survey conducted in 2021, in relation to civic space influencing, the topics for which most of the organizations involved in Masarouna expressed a need on capacity strengthening, are: widening (digital) civic space for young people working on SRHR; protection in digital space; and perception by and relationship with constituency. The topics that were most often indicated by organizations as topics on which they already have a strong capacity and are able to support others on, are: civic space risk mitigation & protection of staff, partners and people we work with; perception by and relationship with consistuency; positive narratives; and strengthening/broadening partnerships (movements & coalitions). (Organisations could express a need, an offer, or both a need and offer on the same topic.)
In addition, the following civic space dimensions were identified by means of the Civic Space Monitoring tool to concentrate capacity strengthening on: access to information and public voice, dialogue and consultation, access to justice and legal services and the legitimacy and accountability of civil society.

Capacity strengthening in relation to civic space influencing will focus on the needs as expressed by respective organisations involved in Masarouna. These include widening (digital) civic space for young people working on SRHR; protection in digital space; and perception by and relationship with constituency.

description.narrative: KI-6 # Women led CSOs/movements capacitated by Masarouna to advocate for safe and adequate SRHR information and services for diverse young people
KI-6 # Youth led CSOs/movements capacitated by Masarouna to advocate for safe and adequate SRHR information and services for diverse young people
EO4 CSOs working with young people have increased their organisational capacities and have increased their civic space influencing capacity (online/offline) on SRHR
KI-12 # CSOs/movements, both women and youth led, supported by Masarouna to strengthen their organizational capacities

comment.narrative: According to the Mutual Capacity Strengthening baseline survey conducted in 2021, in relation to organisational capacity, the topics for which most of the organizations involved in Masarouna expressed a need on capacity strengthening, are: MEAL, in particular feminist MEAL, and fundraising/proposal writing. The topics for which most organizations indicated to already having a strong capacity and being able to support others, are: fundraising, project management and project financial management. (Organisations could express a need, an offer, or both a need and offer on the same topic). According to the Mutual Capacity Strengthening baseline survey conducted in 2021, in relation to x-cutting themes, the topics for which most of the organizations involved in Masarouna expressed a need on capacity strengthening, are: SRHR foundational knowledge, feminist approach to (SRHR) influencing, gender and power analysis, and transformative leadership. The topics for which most organizations indicated to already having a strong capacity and being able to support others, are: youth engagement practices, mainstreaming gender justices and social inclusion, working with specific target groups, and analyzing and integrating conflict sensitivity. (Organisations could express a need, an offer, or both a need and offer on the same topic).

Capacity strengthening in relation to organisational capacities will focus on the needs as expressed by respective organisations involved in Masarouna. These include capacity strengthening on MEAL, in particular feminist MEAL, and fundraising/proposal writing. Capacity strengthening in relation to x-cutting themes will focus on the needs as expressed by respective organisations involved in Masarouna. These include SRHR foundational knowledge, feminist approach to (SRHR) influencing, gender and power analysis, and transformative leadership.

RNW Media will support masterclasses on the use of online data collection, analysis and visualisation to partners. In addition, being a member of RNW Media's network, partners benefit from network members expertise, be hired as technical experts and/or mutual strengthening of their organizational capacities to implement programmes.

LTO 1: Decision-makers have formulated (and implemented where possible) policies, and/or removed/amended harmful policies, to enable young people to enjoy their SRHR.
KI-1a # Governmental policies blocked, adopted and/or improved to enable diverse young people to enjoy their SRHR

comment.narrative: There is no specific law or policy targeting young people's access to their SRHR; SRHR is not included in the national school curriculum.

The project will focus on the design, adoption , and implementation (if the conditions allow) of policies/and or laws specifically targeting young people and their SRHR. According to a preliminary analysis conducted in the baseline, (adapted) SRHR information is not included in the school curriculum. Our goal is to launch a process of designing such curriculum, which would be adopted by the Ministry of Education by the end of the project.

Partnership indicator
KI-16 # CSOs/movements, both women and youth led, engaged in Masarouna

comment.narrative: The partnership portfolio at baseline (2021) is composed of 5 CSOs: 2 both women and youth led, 3 not youth or women led (including Oxfam). One of these CSOs is a social enterprise. In addition it was decided to involve 2 youth led organizations which are fundamental to ensure that the project responds to young people´s needs. All involved CSOs have extensive experience in SRHR.
The 2 both women and youth led CSO engaged in Masarouna conducted activities which ranged from awareness raising, to capacity strengthening and advocacy/lobby.
The partnership portfolio for 2021 shall comprise 5 CSOs: 2 both women and youth led, 3 not youth or women led (including Oxfam), all having experience in SRHR.

The partnership evolution prospect could lead to an official on boarding by Oxfam of two youth-led organizations as partners. After assessing more deeply their capacity levels and strengthen their capacity,they could cover more responsibilities in the direct programme implementation.

description.narrative: KI-16 # CSOs/movements, not women or youth led, engaged in Masarouna

comment.narrative:
The partnership portfolio at baseline (2021) is composed of 5 CSOs: 2 both women and youth led, 3 not youth or women led (including Oxfam). One of these CSOs is a social enterprise. In addition it was decided to involve 2 youth led organizations which are fundamental to ensure that the project responds to young people´s needs. All involved CSOs have extensive experience in SRHR.
Oxfam's awareness of country context, their experience in strengthening the influencing capacities of SRHR-focused partners,managing large grants, innovative sub-granting and learning mechanisms complemented by RNW Media’s expertise in strengthening digital interventions and co-creating digital communities for social change, the partnership brings together different strong elements of each consortium member’s work that add value and maximize Masarouna’s potential for impact.
The 3 not youth or women led CSO engaged in Masarouna conducted activities which ranged from awareness raising, to capacity strengthening and advocacy/lobby.
The partnership portfolio for 2021 shall comprise 5 CSOs: 2 both women and youth led, 3 not youth or women led (including Oxfam), all having experience in SRHR.

The partnership evolution prospect could lead to an official on boarding by Oxfam of two youth-led organizations as partners. After assessing more deeply their capacity levels and strengthen their capacity,they could cover more responsibilities in the direct programme implementation. One not women or youth led CSO (a social enterprise) will cease to be part of the partnership in 2022.
In 2022, 2 partners will be subcontracted by RNW Media, 1 partner will be Oxfam and the other partner will be a result of the partner scoping visit, executed in 2022. During the course of the project, the partnership with Oxfam will be strengthened as the partners get to know each other and each other's strengths better. We would see the partnership evolve through collaboration, joint learning meetings, regular exchanges and possible introduction of new partners, which can be identified through the implementation and assessment of project activities. RNW Media has the ambition to expand its partner base with other types of organisations that can help reaching the Masarouna objectives. For example, research institutes to change social norms and provide evidence-based information for advocacy.

description.narrative: KI-16 # Women led CSOs/movements engaged in Masarouna
KI-16 # Youth led CSOs/movements engaged in Masarouna
Representation indicator
KI-17 # CSOs/movements, both women and youth led, engaged in Masarouna that have enhanced representation of constituencies

comment.narrative:
The CSOs have been selected because of the fact they are currently conducting SRHR activities and targeting young people. With their on-going involvement and throughout the whole cycle of the programme, it is expected that they will have a decisive increase in their representational role.
In the Mutual Capacity Strengthening baseline survey conducted in 2021, most organisations expressed a need for capacity strengthening on perception by and relationship with constituency, and most organisations expressed an offer on youth engagement practices.
The qualitative target will be defined after having conducted a more detailed assessment of the organizations' representational role during Year 2.

description.narrative: KI-17 # CSOs/movements, not women or youth led, engaged in Masarouna that have enhanced representation of constituencies

comment.narrative:
The CSOs have been selected because of the fact they are currently conducting SRHR activities and targeting young people. With their on-going involvement and throughout the whole cycle of the programme, it is expected that they will have a decisive increase in their representational role.
In the Mutual Capacity Strengthening baseline survey conducted in 2021, most organisations expressed a need for capacity strengthening on perception by and relationship with constituency, and most organisations expressed an offer on youth engagement practices.

The qualitative target will be defined after having conducted a more detailed assessment of the organizations' representational role during Year 2.
RNW Media will co-create a session on youth engagement together with partners. After the session partners will have a position on how youth' representation can be enhanced and monitored in our programmes. As a result, actions can be developed, such as "youth councils", youth as community moderators in the interventions, etc. Collecting data with youth themselves on youth needs and youth satisfaction will give insights in what way youth is represented in the programme.
